channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: No Progress Seen in Latest Round of Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Both sides call the talks slow and difficult, and say that gaps remain on the size of enrichment capability Iran would be permitted.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Some Muslims React Warily to Hindu Party’s Victory in India
item.description: In the wake of a landslide electoral triumph by Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu nationalist party, some Muslims said they are worried their place in India could become even more tenuous.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Mine Disaster Casts Harsh Light on Turkey’s Premier
item.description: The accident has metastasized from a local tragedy into a new political crisis for Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who has aggravated public outrage with high-handed remarks.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Miners departed during a break from their search and rescue operation for colleagues trapped after a mining disaster in Soma.

item.title: Russian Rocket Crashes After Takeoff
item.description: A Russian Proton-M rocket carrying a communications satellite crashed in Kazakhstan after what appeared to have been an engine malfunction, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Explosions Kill 10 in Kenya as Western Embassies Warn of Threats
item.description: The blasts struck a market in Nairobi, and two suspects have been arrested, the authorities said, but no group has claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: A crowd gathers in Nairobi where twin explosions claimed lives.

item.title: India Ink: Live-Blogging the Vote Count in India
item.description: India Ink is following the Indian election results throughout the day.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A supporter holding up a placard bearing the portrait of J. Jayalalithaa, chief minister of Tamil Nadu, during celebrations in Chennai, Tamil Nadu on Friday.

item.title: Narendra Modi Prevails in Election
item.description: The victory by Narendra Modi rendered a crushing verdict on the country’s flagging economic growth and a drumbeat of corruption scandals.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Iraqi Novelist, Dodging Bombs, Writes to Clear the Fog of War
item.description: Ahmed Saadawi, who won a top Arabic literary prize, is at the vanguard of a group of writers starting to interpret the trauma of a decade of war.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Max Becherer for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author Ahmed Saadawi in the al-Bataween district of Baghdad, where his award-winning novel, “Frankenstein in Baghdad,” is set.

item.title: Nigerian Leader Cancels Visit to Village of Girls Taken by Boko Haram
item.description: Concerns for the president’s security prompted the decision, which came as West African leaders planned to meet in Paris to discuss the problem.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and ALAN COWELL

item.title: In Vietnam, Indignation Toward China Is Likely to Linger
item.description: The outburst of anti-Chinese violence in Vietnam has exposed how volatile nationalist sentiment can be when it involves rival territorial claims.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and CHAU DOAN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: One Day, One China, 2 Foreign Policy Views
item.description: Two top Chinese officials, President Xi Jinping and the military’s chief of staff, Gen. Fang Fenghui, presented starkly different views of their country’s foreign policy on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Xi Jinping: "The Chinese people do not have the gene for invading others."

item.title: U.N. Cites Rising Human Rights Violations in Ukraine
item.description: A new report warned of an increase in killings, abductions, beatings and detentions of journalists, politicians and activists in the country’s east.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Uighur Biker Takes Message of Peace on the Road
item.description: For the past year, an ethnic Uighur from the restive region of Xinjiang has sought to make amends for his past by traveling across China in support of ethnic harmony.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: Dolkun Tunurganjan has upgraded to motorized transport since beginning his journey on a bicycle a year ago.

item.title: Nigerian Leader Reported to Cancel Visit to Home Village of Kidnapped Girls
item.description: Aides were said to have cited concerns for the president’s security, which highlighted the frailty of government control in the area.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 3 Officials Were Killed in Xinjiang During Chinese President’s Visit, Report Says
item.description: The three government officials, all from China’s dominant Han ethnic group, were slashed and stabbed to death on April 27, the day that President Xi Jinping arrived for a four-day tour of the troubled region.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Uighur children playing on Thursday near a cage that protects heavily armed paramilitary police officers in Urumqi, the regional capital of Xinjiang.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Into Africa: China’s Wild Rush
item.description: Africans are asking just what China’s billions in investment mean for their daily lives and political rights.
item.dc:creator: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

item.title: Lens Blog: Latin America’s Mutating Cities, in Photographs
item.description: An ambitious new exhibit shows the many transformations – social, physical and cultural – that have remade Latin America.
item.category: Museo de Arte del Banco de la República
The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By MAURICE BERGER
item.media:description: Untitled (in situ) [Sin título, (in situ)]. Tijuana, 1997. Collection of Leticia and Stanislas Poniatowski.

item.title: Japan Moves to Scale Back Postwar Restrictions on the Use of Military Power
item.description: A government panel called on the country to adopt a new legal interpretation of its war-renouncing Constitution that would permit an expanded role for its military.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Thursday said a stronger military would allow Japan to contribute to stability in the region.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Ton of Cash Reported in Official’s Home
item.description: A deputy chief of the National Energy Administration’s coal bureau reportedly had a stack of bills so large that it took 16 mechanical bill counters to calculate it.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The 100-renminbi bill is the largest in Chinese currency, adding to the challenges of hoarding 100 million renminbi in cash.

item.title: India Ink: At a Memorial, Hundreds Pay Tribute to a Gujarat Human Rights Champion
item.description: The author remembers Mukul Sinha, a renowned human rights lawyer, who died on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By ZAHIR JANMOHAMED

item.title: Hopes of a Restless Generation Are Riding on India’s Elections
item.description: Despite a period of rising incomes, a tide of economic discontent has helped make the challenger Narendra Modi the front-runner for prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: At Least 29 Killed in Attacks
item.description: Bombings and shootings around Baghdad, Iraq’s capital, killed at least 29 people and wounded dozens on Thursday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Ferry Capsizes
item.description: A ferry carrying more than 100 passengers capsized and sank Thursday in a river in central Bangladesh after a storm, and eight bodies have been recovered, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Heavy Flooding Strikes Balkans
item.description: The heaviest rains and floods in 120 years have hit Bosnia and Serbia, killing five people, forcing hundreds out of their homes and cutting off entire towns.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing : Afghanistan: U.S. Repatriates Pakistanis
item.description: The American military has repatriated 10 Pakistani prisoners whom it had held at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
